item.title: [Berlin, Germany] Celebrating Christmas in the City of the Ampelmann
item.description:
With dreams of a “white Christmas” vacation and images of lively Christmas markets in mind, we boarded our flightÂ to Berlin in December 2013. Â Well, although snow didn’t make an appearance during our trip, we venturedÂ out in (almost) freezing weather to experience the warmth of Berlin’s ChristmasÂ markets. The gaiety, bright lights, colorful stalls, and variety of food and drink lent a magical, festiveÂ touch to the city.

In the capital of Germany, we explored the Christmas markets, visitedÂ historical monuments, learned aboutÂ the Ampelmann, spotted colorful bears (the bear is Berlin’s symbol), Â and spent solemn moments at twoÂ memorials.

At the beautiful Gendarmenmarkt. Berlin, Germany

Festive Cheer at Berlin’s Christmas Markets
Germany’s Christmas markets featured on many blogs that I read. After all the “armchair” travel, here I was in Berlin for the real experience.
From the market at Alexanderplatz to the buzzing activityÂ at Gendarmenmarkt, we hopped from one Christmas market to another. Junior enjoyed a ride onÂ every carousel and little train that he could spot. B and I immersed ourselves in the festive spirit at each location. The glittering lights, the warm comfort food and drinks, friends and families braving the chill to enjoy the outdoor markets – it was a very pretty picture indeed!

Glittering Christmas Lights. Christmas Market, Berlin, Germany 

<p class="wp-caption-text">
  Nativity Scene. Christmas Market, Berlin, Germany
</p>


<p class="wp-caption-text">
  Shining Stars at Gendarmenmarkt. Christmas Market, Berlin, Germany
</p>

Tracing Berlin’s History throughÂ its Monuments and Buildings

BerlinÂ is dotted withÂ majestic monuments and buildings that narrate stories of its tumultuous history.

As we explored the cityÂ on foot, one of theÂ first sights we encountered wasÂ the imposingÂ Reichstag/Bundestag building. 

  <p class="wp-caption-text">
    The magnificent Reichstag/Bundestag building. Berlin, Germany
  </p>
</div>


<div>
  Then, we continued onward toÂ the beautifulÂ Brandenburg Gate.Â This triumphal archÂ is an importantÂ icon of Berlin, and Germany, in general.Â Â As numerous tourists posed for pictures in this pedestrian zone, we wondered about life in the former East Berlin and West Berlin. Today, the Brandenburg Gate is aÂ popular tourist attractionÂ and a venue forÂ severalÂ major events.
</div>

<div>
  <div id="attachment_3620" style="width: 710px" class="wp-caption alignnone">
    <img class="wp-image-3620 size-large" src="http://funderfulworld.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/BrandenburgGate3-1024x676.jpg" alt="The majestic Brandenburg Gate. Berlin, Germany" width="700" height="462" srcset="http://funderfulworld.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/BrandenburgGate3-1024x676.jpg 1024w, http://funderfulworld.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/BrandenburgGate3-300x198.jpg 300w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" />

    <p class="wp-caption-text">
      The majesticÂ Brandenburg Gate. Berlin, Germany
    </p>
  </div>
</div>

<div>
</div>

<div>
</div>

Solemn Moments and a Heavy Heart at the Memorials

While the Christmas Markets brought many a cheer to our hearts, we spent solemn moments at the Berlin Wall Memorial. This memorial broughtÂ back memories ofÂ extremely tough times in the past, of hardÂ partitionsÂ within a country, of a dividing wall and its eventual downfall. 

  <p class="wp-caption-text">
    The Berlin Wall Memorial. Berlin, Germany
  </p>
</div>

I was greatly moved at the Memorial to the Sinti and Roma of Europe. The deafening silence at the memorial, the gentle ripples in the pond, and the lone flower that seemed to represent loss as well as hope painted a complicated picture, one that left me with a heavy heart. 

  <p class="wp-caption-text">
    Solemn Moments at the Memorial to the Sinti and Roma of Europe. Berlin, Germany
  </p>
</div>

A Pleasant Evening Stroll in the Nikolai Quarter (Nikolaiviertel)
The Nikolai Quarter (Nikolaivertel) in Berlin is the perfect neighborhood for a relaxed evening stroll.Â ThisÂ old residential area was destroyed during World War II but was later rebuilt to resemble the original area.
We ambled along the quaintÂ streetsÂ andÂ gazedÂ at the twinkling Christmas lights. The imposing statue of St. George and the Dragon is located along the river. AttractiveÂ shop windows and other smallÂ statuesÂ lend a special touch to this picturesque neighborhood.

The charming Nikolai Quarter. Berlin, Germany

This and That in Berlin
The busÂ route 100Â goes pastÂ many tourist attractions. Junior thoroughly enjoyed our ride on the top deck ofÂ the double decker bus. For our littleÂ transport enthusiast, the sight of the Berlin tram wasÂ icing on the cake.
Speaking of little men, we discovered the Ampelmann at the traffic lights in Berlin. If you visit the city, you will spot these men everywhere!Â For the enthusiasts, there is even an Ampelmann store, complete with all the special merchandise. Yes, we hopped into the store for a quick tour.

The special man, the Ampelmann. Berlin, Germnay

We rounded off our visit to the capital of Germany with an “up close and personal” look at the toweringÂ Berlin TV tower (Fernsehturm) and the Marienkirche (St. Mary’s Church) nearÂ AlexanderPlatz.Â Junior, who isn’t very impressed by tall buildings (doÂ theyÂ have wheels?), played to his heart’s content at a nearbyÂ playground.

Towering above all. TV Tower, Berlin, Germany

Useful Information:
– Berlin local transport info:Â http://www.visitberlin.de/en/article/berlin-s-local-transport
– The SBahnÂ andÂ UBahn provide excellent connectivity in Berlin.
– Bus routes 100 and 200 go past many tourist attractions in Berlin.
– For more information: http://www.visitberlin.de/en

item.title: A Holiday in Hamburg: Stroll, Wander, Discover
item.description:
The highlights of our trip to Hamburg wereÂ LandungsbrÃ¼cken, Hagenbeck Tierpark, and Miniatur Wunderland.

During our stay, we also exploredÂ several parts ofÂ the city on foot. It was an amazing journey of discovery!

Here are some of our favorite picks from this journey:

HafenCity:

At HafenCity, aÂ new developing neighborhood, we climbed the observation tower for a lovely view, walked by the cruise center, observedÂ the Unilever building and Marco Polo tower, wandered aimlessly around Magellan-Terrassen, cooled our heels at Vasco da Gama Platz, walked across Shanghai bridge and admired the canals from here, strolled along Am Kaiserkai Boulevard, and enjoyed a coffee at Osaka Allee. Spend a morning, afternoon, evening, or even an entire day here!

Observation Tower. Hafen City, Hamburg, Germany

Elbphilharmonie Hamburg. Hafen City, Hamburg, Germany

Patterns. Hafen City, Hamburg, Germany

Hafen City, Hamburg, Germany

Hafen City, Hamburg, Germany

Speicherstadt (Warehouse district):

The red brick buildings and the numerous canals give a special touch to Speicherstadt, the tranquil warehouse district. Enjoy a peaceful promenade in this area.

Gaze. Speicherstadt, Hamburg, Germany

Speicherstadt, Hamburg, Germany

Inner Alster and Outer Alster lakes (Binnenalster and AuÃŸenalster):

We loved the picturesqueÂ Inner andÂ Outer Alster lakes and were fortunate toÂ haveÂ ducks and their chicks for company. Take a boat tour, walk along the lake, or just take a nap on the grass! ðŸ™‚

Pick a spot. Alster lake, Hamburg, Germany

Alster lake, Hamburg, Germany

Rathaus:

In the city center, the town hall or RathausÂ is a grand building. You could begin or end your tour of the city here.

Rathaus, Hamburg, Germany

Bismarck Monument:

We walked from LandungsbrÃ¼cken to view thisÂ massive statue of Otto von Bismarck. I thought it was quite impressive!

 

The Iron Man. Statue of Bismarck, Hamburg, Germany

If you get a chance to visit Hamburg, stroll, wander, discover, and enjoyÂ your trip!

item.title: A Holiday in Hamburg: Family Fun!
item.description:
If the curtain-raiser inspired you to visit Hamburg, here are more reasons to book your tickets!

 

Hagenbeck Tierpark, Hamburg, Germany

A Wild Day Out at Tierpark Hagenbeck (Hagenbeck Zoo):

The Tierpark Hagenbeck or Hagenbeck Zoo in HamburgÂ has been owned by the Hagenbeck family for six generations. It was rebuilt after being destroyed during World War II.This vast zoo is characterized by its “open” design; the animals are housed in open enclosures with moats. The endearing elephants, the polar bears and walrusesÂ in the Eismeer, and the beautifully landscaped park and garden make this one of ourÂ favorite zoos.

TheÂ petting zoneÂ brought many a smile to Junior’s face. I couldn’t take my eyes off the pretty picture of pink flamingos and the cherry blossoms. B was fascinatedÂ by the design of the enclosures – at times, you can view several animals in the same frame, just as they would be spotted co-existing in the wild.

Who goes there? Hagenbeck Tierpark, Hamburg, Germany

Pleased to meet you. Hagenbeck Tierpark, Hamburg, Germany

Pink. Cherry blossoms and flamingos, Hagenbeck Tierpark, Hamburg, Germany

Two’s company. Hagenbeck Tierpark, Hamburg, Germany

Basking in the sun. Hagenbeck Tierpark, Hamburg, Germany

Hagenbeck Tierpark, Hamburg, Germany

As you walk around the zoo, turn around every once in a while for incredible views – of animals and the surroundings. This place is quite a wonder.

There is also an aquariumÂ here.Â Our zoo visit took an entire day, and so, we decided to meetÂ our aquatic friends another time.

 

Useful Information:

http://www.hagenbeck.de/en/tierpark/start.html

http://english.hamburg.de/hagenbeck/nofl/3637950/hagenbeck-zoo/

 

The World of Trains atÂ Miniatur Wunderland:

Our best experience at Hamburg was at this wonderful land of miniature railways. Do not miss it for the world!

Choof choof! Miniatur Wunderland, Hamburg, Germany

Junior had been fervently counting everyÂ hour, minute, and second until it was our turn to enter Miniatur Wunderland. Although we had initially planned to visit the attractionÂ in the morning, it was quite crowded at that time, and we managed to get tickets only for a later slot in the day.

As the evening air turned chilly in Hamburg, we headed indoors, into the fascinating miniature world of trains. ICE trains zipped along, Amtrak trains chugged on, SBB trains moved at varying speeds across the beautiful Swiss landscape – an incredible sight! Over the next few hours, we walkedÂ from one zoneÂ in the museum to another, from Hamburg to America, from Scandinavia to Austria, from Switzerland to the Knuffingen airport, and the attention to detail in the models amazed us. Signals, train stations, landscapes, people… everything in miniature! Needless to say, the young train aficionado in our family was shouting with joy and exclaiming in wonder throughoutÂ our visit (that lasted almost 3 hours :)). When we left the museum, his voice has turned quite hoarse :).

Chugging along. Miniatur Wunderland, Hamburg, Germany

It’s a small world! Miniatur Wunderland, Hamburg, Germany

Hamburg Hauptbahnhof. Miniatur Wunderland, Hamburg, Germany

Las Vegas! Miniatur Wunderland, Hamburg, Germany

Winter! Minatur Wunderland, Hamburg, Germany

Switzerland, the land of SBB! Miniatur Wunderland, Hamburg, Germany

Get set go! Knuffingen Airport, Miniatur Wunderland, Hamburg, Germany

Junior loved every single train in every section of Miniatur Wunderland. My favorite zone was Switzerland, which extended over two storeys. I had to tear B away from the Knuffingen airport, a fascinating area, with scheduled landingsÂ andÂ take-offs of aircraft.

 

Tip:

During holidays and peak season, it is recommended to buy tickets in advance.

UsefulÂ Information:

http://www.miniatur-wunderland.com

 

More reasons to visit Hamburg?Â ReadÂ the next post! ðŸ™‚

A Holiday in Hamburg: Stroll, Wander, Discover

item.title: A Holiday in Hamburg: Port on the Elbe
item.description:
The Free and Hanseatic city of Hamburg was a sudden and unexpected entrant on our list of travel destinations this year. And what a fantastic trip it turned out to be!

The Hamburg skyline from Steinwerder. Hamburg, Germany

In spring this year, we got lucky with flight ticket deals and seized the opportunityÂ to spend a few days in Hamburg. This large German port city on the River Elbe revealedÂ a world of cargo shipsÂ andÂ cruise ferries, old warehouses andÂ modern districts, picturesque lakes and verdant parks.

 

LandungsbrÃ¼cken, Ships Galore

For first impressions of Hamburg, head to LandungsbrÃ¼cken, the perfect place to watch the world go by. Ferries to distant landsÂ andÂ cargo ships from across the seas vie for attention at the harbor here. Take a promenade along the river Elbe, gaze at boats of all sizes, grab a bite to eat, and say “Hello Hamburg!”

 

LandungsbrÃ¼cken. Hamburg, Germany

Love is in the air! LandungsbrÃ¼cken. Hamburg, Germany

Sail on! LandungsbrÃ¼cken. Hamburg, Germany

 

The Tunnel below the Elbe (From LandungsbrÃ¼cken to Steinwerder)

Ready forÂ an exciting walk?

The old Elbe tunnel is open to pedestrians! From LandungsbrÃ¼cken, you can walk under the wide river and cross overÂ to Steinwerder. It was aÂ fascinating experience for us. Junior,Â excited to jog under the Elbe, had numerousÂ questions about the construction of the tunnel.

On the other side, atÂ Steinwerder, enjoy the pretty sights ofÂ the Hamburg skyline and harbor across the river.

The old Elbe tunnel. LandungsbrÃ¼cken, Hamburg, Italy

The Hamburg skyline from Steinwerder. Hamburg, Germany

Docked. LandungsbrÃ¼cken, Hamburg, Germany

 

A Ferry Ride (From LandungsbrÃ¼cken to Finkenwerder)

I am fascinated by harbors and could spend many an hour watching the action at a port. If you have the time, hop on to the HVV ferry line 62 from LandungsbrÃ¼cken to Finkenwerder for an enjoyable (and inexpensive) ride along the harbor. Â At Finkenwerder, we grabbed a coffee and then relaxed at a tranquil spot before embarking on the return journey.

Finkenwerder, Hamburg, Germany

Ferry ride! Hamburg, Germany

Car-go! Hamburg, Germany

 

And that, dear readers, was just a curtain-raiser.Â There’s much more to see and do in Hamburg, as we discovered. Stay tuned for more recommendations! ðŸ™‚

 

Useful Links:

Tourist Information:Â http://english.hamburg.de/tourist-information/

Public Transport:Â http://www.hvv.de/en/index.php
